abstract.para:
In this unit you will learn how to
Say 'hello' and 'goodbye'
Exchange greetings
Observe basic courtesies
Ask people to speak more slowly

section.title: Before you start
section.para: Read the Introduction to the course. This gives some useful advice on studying alone and how to make the most of the course.

Make sure you've got your recording next to you as you'll need it to listen to the Pronunciation guide and Dialogues sections. If you don't have the recording, use the Pronunciation guide in the book.

section.title: Study tips
section.para: Remember that studying for 20 minutes regularly is better than occassionally spending two hours in one go.

listitem.para: Listen to the Dialogues once or twice without the book (read them if you haven't got the recording).
Go over each one, bit by bit, in conjunction with the Key words and phrases and notes underneath the dialogues.
Read the Grammar section very carefully and study it.
Read the tips on How to learn vocabulary and How to pronounce.
Go back to the Dialogues and Key words and phrases for more listening and studying, this time using the pause button and repeating aloud after the recording.
Do the Activities including Things to remember, check your answers in the Key to the exercises and tests and test yourself with the Self-test.

section.para: Essayez! Have a go! Can you think of any French words you know such as the words for 'hello' and 'thank you'? Say them out loud, and then look at the Key words and phrases to check the answers.

row.entry: I am well - how about you?

note.para: When you see a linking mark '_' between two words, sound the last letter of the first word as though it were attached to the next word: vous parlez_anglais?

section.title: Dialogues
section.para: Listen to the recording and hear people practicing saying 'hello' and greeting each other in French.
Press the pause button after each sentence and repeat aloud.

note.para: Pay particular attention to the way the 's' in Messieurs and Monsieur is pronounced. It should sound as in pass and not as in shop.

row.entry: Je vais très bien Rosine, et toi?
Au revoir, Madame et ... merci beaucoup.
Bonjour, Madame. Qu'est-ce que vous désirez?
Parlez plus lentement, s'il vous plaît.

note.para: Qu'est-ce que vous désirez? (lit.) What do you wish? but used in shops it means Can I help you?

listitem.para: As a general rule don't pronounce d g p s t x z at the end of a word, e.g. beaucoup vous nuit plaît.
The letter e often gets swallowed as in mad'moiselle.
The stress, in French, is on the last part of the word: par-don mer-ci mad'-moi-selle mon-sieur.
ç placed before o, u, a is pronounced as s as in sit: garçon, ça va?
The s in monsieur is pronounced as ss in pass.

section.title: SIMPLE QUESTIONS
section.para: The simplest way of asking something in French is to raise your voice on the last syllable (part of a word):
Now practise saying pardon? (to have something repeated) and pardon (to apologize or attract someone's attention).

section.title: REFUSING POLITELY IN FRENCH
section.para: If you want to refuse something in France, you can say non merci or merci on its own.

section.title: CALLING THE WAITER'S ATTENTION
section.para: Although garçon is the word for waiter, today you would usually say Monsieur to attract his attention. For a waitress, you say Madame or Mademoiselle as you think fir or just look expectant and say s'il vous plaît.

note.para: Don't forget to shorten Mademoiselle to Mad'moiselle to make it sound more French!

section.title: HOW TO BE COURTEOUS
section.para: In France when you're talking to someone you don't know very well, it's polite to add Monsieur, Madame, Mademoiselle particularly after short phrases like oui, non, bonjour or merci.
The French shake hands with good friends and acquaintances every time they meet or say goodbye. Kissing (on both cheeks) is reserved for family and close friends.

section.title: WHEN TO USE TU (YOU) AND WHEN TO USE VOUS (YOU)
section.para: The equivalent of you in French can be either tu or vous. French people use tu when speaking to children, teenagers, relations and close friends. They use vous in work and business situations or when speaking to senior or old people: vous is also used to address a group of people to whom one might say tu individually. The best advice is to say vous until you are addressed as tu or asked to use the tu form: on se tutoie? shall we call each other tu?

section.title: HOW TO LEARN VOCABULARY
section.para: There are several ways of learning vocabulary. Find the way that works best for you; here are a few suggestions:

listitem.para: Say the words out loud as you read them.
Write the words over and over again.
Listen to the recordings several times.
Study the list from the beginning to end then backwards.
Associate the French words with similar sounding words in English, e.g. parlez with parlour, a room where people chat.
Associate the words with pictures or situations, e.g. bonjour, bonsoir with shaking hands.
Use coloured pencils to underline/group the words in a way that will help you to remember them.

Copy the words on to small cards or slips of paper, English on one side, French on the other. Study them in varying order giving the French word if the card comes out with the English on top, or vice versa.
